company.name: Jones O. Godwin
company.business_description: Operator of skidekids.com, a child-directed social networking website promoted as the 'Facebook and Myspace for kids' serving children ages 7 to 14.

case_info.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c) and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

complaint.factual_background: Jones O. Godwin operated Skid-e-kids (www.skidekids.com), a social networking website marketed as 'the social networking alternative for kids ages 7 to 14.' Despite his privacy policy claiming the site required a parent's email address to activate a child's account and notify parents of registration, Godwin never actually collected parent email addresses, never notified parents, and never obtained parental consent before collecting personal information from children. He collected and maintained personal information from approximately 5,600 children in violation of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA Rule) and Section 5 of the FTC Act.

representations_made.description: Claimed that the website requires child users to provide a parent's valid email address in order to register, and that this information is used to send the parent an activation message and notify the parent about the site's privacy practices
representations_made.quoted_text: The Skid-e-kids.com website requires child users to provide a parent's valid email address in order to register on the website. We use this information to send the parent a message that can be used to activate the Skid-e kids account, to notify the parent about our privacy Rractices, to send the .parent communications either about the parent's and child s Skid-e-kids accounts or about features of our Web site, and for the other purposes described in this Privacy Policy. This email address is correlated with the account user name.

counts.title: Violations of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA Rule)
counts.representation: Defendant collected, used, and/or disclosed personal information from children through the Skid-e-kids website since 2009
counts.fact: Defendant failed to: (a) provide sufficient notice on his website of information collection practices; (b) provide direct notice to parents of collection, use, and disclosure practices; and (c) obtain verifiable parental consent before collecting, using, or disclosing personal information from children
counts.conclusion: Therefore, Defendant has violated the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 312.

counts.title: Violations of the FTC Act — Deceptive Misrepresentation
counts.representation: Through statements in his privacy policy, Defendant represented that he collects a parent's online contact information in order to notify the parent of a child's registration, to permit the parent to activate the child's account, and to notify the parent of Defendant's privacy practices
counts.fact: In truth and in fact, Defendant registered children without ever collecting a parent's email, sending the parent a notice of their information practices, or providing parents with a means to assent to their children's participation
counts.conclusion: Therefore, the representation set forth in Paragraph 23 was false and misleading, constituting a deceptive act or practice in violation of Section 5(a) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a).

definitions.Rule: the Federal Trade Commission's Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 312.
definitions.child, collects, collection, Commission,: mean as those terms are defined in Section 312.2 of the Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 312.2.
definitions.Defendant: Jones O. Godwin, individually, and doing business through any name, including but not limited to Skid-e-kids Network LLC, and www.skidekids.com.

provisions.title: Injunction – COPPA Compliance Requirements
provisions.summary: Defendant and those acting in concert with him are permanently enjoined from failing to provide required privacy notices, direct parental notice, and verifiable parental consent, and from violating any other provision of the COPPA Rule.

requirements.description: Must not fail to provide sufficient notice of information collection practices on any website or online service directed to children or through which Defendant collects personal information from children, as required by Rule Section 312.4(b)

provisions.title: Consumer Education Remedy – FTC Notice Posting
provisions.summary: For five years from the Order's entry date, Defendant must post a clear and conspicuous FTC consumer education notice linking to OnGuardOnline.gov within required privacy policies, direct parental notices, and at each location where personal information is collected.

requirements.description: For a period of five (5) years from the date of entry of this Order, place a clear and conspicuous notice within the privacy policy required by Rule Section 312.4(b), within the direct notice required by Rule Section 312.4(c), and at each location on the website where personal information is collected, directing visitors to OnGuardOnline.gov for FTC tips on protecting kids' privacy online

provisions.title: Retention of Children's Online Privacy Professional
provisions.summary: Defendant must retain a qualified independent third-party children's privacy professional to conduct annual assessments for five years, or alternatively maintain membership in a Commission-approved COPPA safe harbor program for five years.

requirements.description: Within thirty (30) days of service of this Order, retain a qualified, objective, independent third-party professional with a minimum of three (3) years of experience in the field of children's online privacy and implementation of the Rule, approved by the Associate Director for Enforcement, Bureau of Consumer Protection, FTC, to conduct initial and annual assessments covering each of five annual reporting periods

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The Commission has broad authority to monitor Defendant's compliance, including through written requests, document production, depositions, facility inspections, undercover posing, and interviews of Defendant's personnel.

requirements.description: Within ten (10) days of receipt of a written request from a Commission representative, Defendant shall submit written responses sworn under penalty of perjury, produce documents for inspection and copying, appear for deposition, and provide entry during normal business hours to any business location in Defendant's possession or control to inspect business operations

provisions.title: Record-Keeping Provisions
provisions.summary: For eight years from the Order's entry date, Defendant must create and retain records sufficient to demonstrate full compliance with this Order, including acknowledgment copies, compliance reports, and sample web pages and documents regarding collection practices.

requirements.description: For a period of eight (8) years from the date of entry of this Order, for any business for which Defendant is the majority owner or directly or indirectly controls, create and retain: (1) a print or electronic copy of all documents necessary to demonstrate full compliance with each provision of this Order, including copies of Order acknowledgments, all reports submitted to the Commission, and sample copies of every materially different form page or screen through which personal information is collected or disclosed, and a sample copy of each materially different document containing any representation regarding Defendant's collection, use, and disclosure practices pertaining to personal information of a child

provisions.title: Distribution of Order
provisions.summary: For five years from the Order's entry date, Defendant must deliver copies of the Order to principals, managers, and relevant employees of any business he controls, and to principals and managers of any business where he engages in relevant conduct, and must obtain signed acknowledgments within thirty days of delivery.

requirements.description: For any business Defendant controls or has a majority ownership interest in, deliver a copy of this Order to all principals, officers, directors, and managers, and all employees, agents, and representatives with responsibilities related to the operation of any website or online service subject to this Order, and to any business entity resulting from any change in structure; for current personnel, delivery shall be within five (5) days of service of this Order upon Defendant; for new personnel, delivery shall occur prior to their assuming their responsibilities
